title: Who knows this lead script font?
content:
It might be a Schriftguss AG font, but I’m not sure (all fonts in this cabinet were from Schriftguss, when I got it. That’s all.).

Of course I mirrored and turned it 180° to make it easier for you to identify.

Does someone know this font?  
However: Thank’s in advance for your help.

Georg

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/Unknown%20001_3519.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/Unknown%20002_4856.jpg)

 [‹ (x) Fine Arts Connection - Shelley Andante, ITC Edwardian Script {Marcelo R}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36745 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Classic Canada logo - (similar to) Baskerville Old Face {Florian} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36737 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Bleisetzer

comments.content:
There seems to be some resemblances between the initials in this script and Poppl Exquisit. The H is quite similar, and one of the A versions is closer to Exquisit. However, only certain letters are similar, and the lower case is quite different. Unfortunately my books show little in the European scripts, so I have no idea whether Friedrich Poppl designed many other script typefaces, besides this and Residenz. This is what I would look for, as a starting place.

- Mike Yanega

Hello Mike,  
I try to touch the old types only once.  
So I take it out of the cabinet, clean, check and classify it and place it into my online-magazine to offer it to my customers.

With your help, I’ll find it.  
Today I emptied the cabinet. That was important to improve my turnover - otherwise my family will be hungry next month.

[http://www.bleisetzer.de/cms/front\_content.php?idcat=69&rubrik=&maxday\_i...](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.bleisetzer.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=69&rubrik=&maxday_in=20070828&article_id=853 "http://www.bleisetzer.de/cms/front\_content.php?idcat=69&rubrik=&maxday\_in=20070828&article\_id=853")

Thanks again for your help.  
Its good to know someone anywhere in the world who’s crazy enough, too, to love these old types. Visit me in Germany if you will travel Europe...

Georg  
 [www.bleisetzer.de](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.bleisetzer.de/ "www.bleisetzer.de")

I think I have to give it up.

Its not Phyllis  
 [http://www.identifont.com/show?4AU](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.identifont.com/show?4AU "http://www.identifont.com/show?4AU")  
what was Wieynck Kursiv  
 [www.klingspor-museum.de/KlingsporKuenstler/Schriftdesigner/Wieynck/HWiey...](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.klingspor-museum.de/KlingsporKuenstler/Schriftdesigner/Wieynck/HWieynck.pdf "www.klingspor-museum.de/KlingsporKuenstler/Schriftdesigner/Wieynck/HWieynck.pdf")

how Joerg Lepping on [www.typoforum.de](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.typoforum.de/ "www.typoforum.de") thought.

And its not Comtess Lola from Norddeutsche Schriftgiesserei, Berlin, how Siegfried.1 thoguth.  
 [http://www.global-type.org/Schriften.567.0.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200503/http:/www.global-type.org/Schriften.567.0.html "http://www.global-type.org/Schriften.567.0.html")

Both is familiar to it, but its not the font.  
What a mess. I am searching since half a year or so...

Georg

Can somone point me to something similar to this (digital). This may be exactly what I am looking for right now. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,

Hildebrant.
